descr: A triangular sail set upon a stay or halyard extending from the foremast or fore-topmast to the bowsprit or the jib boom. Large vessels often carry several jibe; as, inner jib; outer jib; flying jib; etc.
The projecting arm of a crane, from which the load is suspended.
To move restively backward or sidewise, -- said of a horse; to balk.
A horse that jibs.
of Jibe
of Jibe
To shift, as the boom of a fore-and-aft sail, from one side of a vessel to the other when the wind is aft or on the quarter. See Gybe.
To change a ship\'s course so as to cause a shifting of the boom. See Jibe, v. t., and Gybe.
To agree; to harmonize.
A moment; an instant; as, I will be ready in a jiffy.
A light, brisk musical movement.
A light, humorous piece of writing, esp. in rhyme; a farce in verse; a ballad.
A piece of sport; a trick; a prank.
A trolling bait, consisting of a bright spoon and a hook attached.
A small machine or handy tool
A contrivance fastened to or inclosing a piece of work, and having hard steel surfaces to guide a tool, as a drill, or to form a shield or templet to work to, as in filing.
An apparatus or a machine for jigging ore.
of Jig
of Jig
To sing to the tune of a jig.
To trick or cheat; to cajole; to delude.
To sort or separate, as ore in a jigger or sieve. See Jigging, n.
To cut or form, as a piece of metal, in a jigging machine.
To dance a jig; to skip about.
A species of flea (Sarcopsylla, / Pulex, penetrans), which burrows beneath the skin. See Chigoe.
One who, or that which, jigs; specifically, a miner who sorts or cleans ore by the process of jigging; also, the sieve used in jigging.
A horizontal table carrying a revolving mold, on which earthen vessels are shaped by rapid motion; a potter\'s wheel.
A templet or tool by which vessels are shaped on a potter\'s wheel.
A light tackle, consisting of a double and single block and the fall, used for various purposes, as to increase the purchase on a topsail sheet in hauling it home; the watch tackle.
A small fishing vessel, rigged like a yawl.
A supplementary sail. See Dandy, n., 2 (b).
A pendulum rolling machine for slicking or graining leather; same as Jack, 4 (i).
The act or using a jig; the act of separating ore with a jigger, or wire-bottomed sieve, which is moved up and down in water.
Resembling, or suitable for, a jig, or lively movement.
Playful; frisky.
To wriggle or frisk about; to move awkwardly; to shake up and down.
A jolting motion; a jogging pace.
Having a jolting motion.
A young woman; a sweetheart. See Gill.
A light, giddy, or wanton girl or woman. See Gill-flirt.
A woman who capriciously deceives her lover; a coquette; a flirt.
of Jilt
of Jilt
To cast off capriciously or unfeeling, as a lover; to deceive in love.
To play the jilt; to practice deception in love; to discard lovers capriciously.
See Gimcrack.
A machine for bending or straightening rails.
A planing machine with a reversing tool, to plane both ways.
of Jimmy
A short crowbar used by burglars in breaking open doors.
Neat; handsome; elegant. See Gimp.
See Jamestown weed.
Alt. of Jinn
See Jinnee.
A small portable piece of ordnance, mounted on a swivel.
To sound with a fine, sharp, rattling, clinking, or tinkling sound; as, sleigh bells jingle.
To rhyme or sound with a jingling effect.
of Jingle
of Jingle
To cause to give a sharp metallic sound as a little bell, or as coins shaken together; to tinkle.
A rattling, clinking, or tinkling sound, as of little bells or pieces of metal.
That which makes a jingling sound, as a rattle.
A correspondence of sound in rhymes, especially when the verse has little merit; hence, the verse itself.
One who, or that which, jingles.
The act or process of producing a jingle; also, the sound itself; a chink.
So as to jingle.
of Jingo
A word used as a jocular oath.
A statesman who pursues, or who favors, aggressive, domineering policy in foreign affairs.
The policy of the Jingoes, so called. See Jingo, 2.
of Jinnee
A genius or demon; one of the fabled genii, good and evil spirits, supposed to be the children of fire, and to have the power of assuming various forms.
An inclined road in a coal mine, on which loaded cars descend by gravity, drawing up empty ones.
A small, two-wheeled, hooded vehicle drawn by one more men.
A waistcoat or kind of stays for women.
